bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, July 1, 1875

div1.p: Reed expresses his devotion to Emilie Lawrence. He admires her forgiving spirit, and writes her poetry. He writes to her mother to confirm their engagement, and reports that the photograph he had made of himself in uniform will be ready soon.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, July 1, 1875
div1.p:
I wrote you, on
Monday last, a very short letter,
but I hope to make some amends
for it, this morning. I sometimes
regret that I am not constituted
like those, who are able to write
a long & interesting letter, by jot-
ting down, each day, some item
of news, and combining the whole
into a pleasant narrative. Unlike
these, I cannot draw on the stores
of the Past, but must rely solely
on the Present, & when my task
is once begun, must finish it, at
“one sitting,” as they say -- In truth,
if I expect to accomplish anything in
writing ,I must always do it
under “whip & spur-” This will
account for the want of connection
which often exist between various
parts of my letters, but which is
so necessary to give a charm &
vigor to the whole. No one could
be more sensible of this defect
than myself- What would I not
give if I could only translate my
thoughts into words which should
drop from my pen “like silver
flowing”- But alas! as I cannot ex-
pect this, I will not enter into an
uninteresting disquisition on
Composition.

Your very sweet letter
was received on Tuesday- You
may know how happy I feel in
receiving a letter from you, my
little sweetheart, every week.
Indeed, my darling, you are the
very “pink of promptness-” I am
certain that when I reached my Post
& have a permanent habitation,
that your dear little letters will
arrive as regularly as the sun
rises. And then how happy &
contented will they make me!
To know that, though “much land
& water” separate us, yet that I
am yet remembered by a sweet
angel! And as I watch “our
gem of the sky,“ how very near
to you I shall be! Shall anyone
then talk to me of finding “one that
better pleases me”? A “fig” for all
resolutions thus easily broken!
I know nothing of the either the
lady or gentleman of whom you
spoke in your letter, but I do know
that he has never truly loved
her. I know you say, “ah! but
poor human nature is so frail
& changeable, & we cannot tell what
a day may bring forth.” Very true!
The man or woman does not breathe
who has less confidence in the
steadfastness of the human heart,
taken as a whole, than myself-
But, “Heaven of the Blest,” is there
naught of truth on earth! Is there
no spark of manliness or honor
yet alive in the human breast!
Is life but one interminable night
of darkness! And do all of its
fruits “turn to ashes” on our lips!
Are all things false! Is there
no rock upon which we may safe-
ly stand! Ah! see that trembling
lip & that moistened eye; feel
the press of that warm hand,
and tell me if there is not
some truth yet on earth-! And
are we to so soon to forget these
things! What kind of natures
have we, if these sacred impres-
sions are so quickly effaced!
No! my darling, tell me not of re-
leasing me, if another please me
more! I know it shows a for-
giving spirit- I believe that you
would forego your own pleasure
if you thought it would increase
another's happiness -- but not-
withstanding this, such words fall
upon my heart like a cold show-
er! And although it may show
a spirit of selfishness, on my
part, I would not be willing to
give you up should you meet
one who “pleased you better”-
I never could give you up! (Save
to the God who gave you being)-
Give you up! I to be tossed on
life's tempestuous sea without an
anchor!

lg.l: My heart from bursting through its cage!

div1.p:
These lines are but poor poe-
try, but they have one recom-
mendation & that is, they come
from the heart, & coming from
the heart, defy all criticism!

The hour for mailing my
letter is nearly at hand & I must
hasten to the end of my letter-
I wrote to your mother, yesterday,
& as you requested, I got Mrs V.
to direct the letter -- also put it
in one of her envelopes, so that
no one can possibly suspect
anything- Who are these people
that tease you so much? I
regret that I can't be present to
share the teasing with you-
About my coming to M. As I
wrote you in my last, I am
not certain that I can come-
If I am ordered, at once, to
such a post, of course, I can-
not possibly come without
disobeying orders & risking
my position -- Rest assured of
this one thing- If it is possible
for me to come to Murfreesbo-
ro- I'll certainly come-
The photographs will be ready
to-day, but not in time to go
in this letter- will forward
it this afternoon, so that you
will get it Monday- Ma received
a letter from you, yesterday- She
and Mrs. V. send much love-
div1.closer:
Believe me, darling, as ever,
Affectionately and
devotedly yours, Walter-
